metadata.title: Transcriptional profiling of immune and inflammatory responses in the context of 1 SARS-CoV-2 fungal superinfection in a human airway epithelial model 2 3

abstract.text: 20 Superinfections of bacterial/fungal origin are known to affect the course and severity of 21 respiratory viral infections. An increasing number of evidence indicate a relatively high 42 CoV) that emerged in 2003 and 2012, respectively. These viruses are also transmitted from 43 animals to humans and cause severe respiratory diseases in afflicted individuals. 44 45 In a short period of time, significant effort has been devoted to understanding the molecular 46 basis of the pathology associated with SARS-CoV-2 infection in an attempt to guide work on 47 treatment, vaccine and diagnostic test development. Numerous clinical studies have reported 48 the pathophysiology of COVID-19 has similar aspects to that initially described for SARS-CoV,

i.e. acute lung injury due to over-inflammation following early stages driven by infection and 50 viral replication (Chen et al., 2020; Guan et al., 2020; Huang et al., 2020; Mehta et al., 2020; 51 Zhu et al., 2020). Nevertheless, the particular underlying mechanisms of these exuberant 52 inflammatory responses in SARS-CoV-2 infection remain largely unknown and there is a need 53 to expand our knowledge of the host's response. In this context, several recent omics-based 54 approaches, including in vivo and in vitro transcriptional profiling studies, have highlighted 55 specific aspects of the signature of infection that could contribute to COVID-19 (Blanco-Melo 56 et al., 2020; Gordon et al., 2020; Messina et al., 2020; Xiong et al., 2020). Blanco-Melo and 57 colleagues, using transcriptional and serum profiling of COVID-19 patients, have notably 58 shown that the SARS-CoV-2 infection signature was defined by low levels of Type I and III 59 interferons juxtaposed to elevated chemokines and high expression of IL-6 (Blanco-Melo et 60 al., 2020).

It is now well known that superinfections of bacterial/fungal origin can affect the course and 63 severity of respiratory viral infections. For example, the co-pathogenesis of viruses and 64 bacteria into the lung has been extensively studied, notably in the context of influenza 65 superinfection by bacteria such as S. pneumoniae (Bosch et al., 2013; McCullers, 2014; 66 Morens et al., 2008; Paget and Trottein, 2019). To date, there are limited data available on 67 superinfections associated with COVID-19, though superinfections were reported in 10%-20% 68 of SARS-CoV-2-infected adults admitted to Wuhan hospitals through the end of January 2020, 69 and notably in 50%-100% of those who died (Zhou et al., 2020). In intensive care units, COVID-70 19 patients are at high risk of developing secondary infections, including fungal infections e.g. 71 4 invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (Lescure et al., 2020). Indeed, a recent study on the French 72 COVID-19 cohort reported that 33% of critically ill COVID-19 patients also showed invasive 73 aspergillosis (Alanio et al., 2020). However, while the reasons for increased vulnerability to 74 Aspergillus in COVID-19 patients remain undetermined, the putative contribution of Aspergillus 75 to SARS-CoV-2 related lung inflammation and COVID-19 pathophysiology also constitutes a 76 major unanswered question. 77 78 To better understand the biological impact of superinfection in the SARS-CoV-2 context we 79 sought to determine and compare the host transcriptional response to SARS-CoV-2 versus 80 that of a SARS-CoV-2 + Aspergillus superinfection. To reach this goal, we established a model 81 of SARS-CoV-2 infection and superinfection in reconstituted human airway epithelia (HAE), 82 based on previously published works (Nicolas de Lamballerie et al., 2019; Pizzorno et al., 2019, 83 2020). Our analysis reveals that both simple infection and superinfection induce a strong 84 deregulation of core components of innate immune and inflammatory responses, however, it 85 also highlights unique transcriptional footprints of the SARS-CoV-2 + Aspergillus 86 superinfection that provide valuable insight for the understanding not only of Aspergillus-87 associated COVID-19 but also for the management of severe forms of aspergillosis. 88 89 90 RESULTS 91 92 In order to identify similarities and differences between the host response to SARS-CoV-2 93 simple infection and Aspergillus superinfection, we sought to investigate the transcriptome of 94 human respiratory epithelial cells during infection, in comparison with non-infected cells. Aware 95 of the inherent limitations of experimental models using cell lines, we set up a model of 96 infection/superinfection in a physiological model of reconstituted human airway epithelium 97 (HAE). Developed from biopsies of nasal or bronchial cells differentiated in the air/liquid 98 interphase, these HAE models, that we previously used with different respiratory viruses 99 including SARS-CoV-2 (Nicolas de Lamballerie et al., 2019; Pizzorno et al., 2019, 2020) 100 reproduce with high fidelity most of the main structural, functional and innate immune features 101 of the human respiratory epithelium that play a central role during infection, hence constituting 102 an interesting surrogate to study airway disease mechanisms. We infected nasal or bronchial 103 HAE with SARS-CoV-2, and superinfection with Aspergillus was performed at 48 hours post-104 infection (hpi), which we had previously defined as the peak of acute SARS-CoV-2 infection in 105 the HAE model (Pizzorno et al., 2020). Mock-infected, infected (CoV) and superinfected 106 samples (CoV+Asp) were harvested at 72 hpi (24 h after superinfection) to perform mRNA-

and apical release of IL-6, which we used as hallmarks of infection ( Fig. 2A) . Interestingly, in 110 contrast with nasal HAE, we observed a significative increase on the relative viral production 111 in the context of superinfection in bronchial HAE, associated with higher IL-6 levels and a 112 stronger negative impact on trans-epithelial resistance (Fig. 1B) . 113 114 Differential expression analysis of mRNA-seq data compared to the mock-infected condition 115 identified 1638 and 454 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) in SARS-CoV-2-infected nasal 116 and bronchial HAE, respectively (FC ≥ 2, Benjamini-Hochberg adjusted p-value < 0.01). In the 117 context of CoV+Asp superinfection, the number of DEGs was notably higher, with 2979 and 118 3235 genes in nasal and bronchial HAE, respectively (Extended data. File 1). Interestingly, 119 there was an important overlap between CoV infection and CoV+Asp superinfection 120 associated DEGs in both nasal and bronchial models. As illustrated in the Venn diagrams (Fig. 121 1C), more than 96% (nasal HAE) and 99% (bronchial HAE) of DEGs of the CoV signature 122 were also part of the CoV+Asp signature. To provide further functional interpretation of the 123 global transcriptional signatures, we performed a functional enrichment analysis on the CoV 124 and CoV+Asp nasal and bronchial models using the web-based DAVID toolkit. Gene Ontology 125 (GO), UniProt (KW) and Reactome (RC) terms where considered enriched when their 126

Bonferroni-adjusted corrected enrichment p-value was < 0.01 (Fig. 1D) . As anticipated, a large 127 part of the most enriched and shared terms between all experimental conditions was related 128 to the host response to infection (Regulation of response to cytokine stimulus, regulation of 129 defense response, regulation of response to biotic stimulus) and also to cornification, which 130 regroups genes mostly involved in cell-death mechanisms (Fig. 1D) . Interestingly, functional 131 enrichments specific to CoV infection or CoV+Asp superinfection were also highlighted. For 132 example, CoV infection but no superinfection induced the upregulation of a gene cluster 133 involved in Type I interferon pathway (Fig. 1D) . Conversely, gene clusters harboring terms 134 associated with epithelium physiology and cilium movements (regulation of cellular component 135 movements, cell projection assembly, intraflagellar transport) but also with intra and extra-136 cellular signaling (post-translational protein phosphorylation, protein localization to 137 extracellular membrane, peptide secretion) were exclusively enriched in the context of 138 CoV+Asp superinfection (Fig. 1D) . In parallel, given the importance of the exacerbated 139 immune response observed mainly in severe COVID-19 cases, we further analyzed the 140 inflammation-related terms and identified similar, yet to a different extent, regulation patterns 141 for genes involved in the positive regulation of inflammatory response (GO:0050729) between 142 nasal and bronchial HAE. As exemplified in the heatmap (Fig. 1D) , deregulated genes such 143 as calgranulin coding genes S100A12 and S100A9/A8 and downregulated genes such as 157 performed a differential analysis of CoV+Asp signature using that of CoV infection as baseline.

This focused analysis highlighted 248 and 769DEGs in the CoV+Asp nasal and bronchial HAE, 159 respectively (FC ≥ 2, adjusted p-value < 0.01), which allowed us to spot finer differences 160 between the two epithelium models. Indeed, the volcano plots in Fig. 2A and B representing

161 all DEGs induced by the CoV+Asp versus the CoV condition show interesting differences in 162 both the scale of deregulation and the nature of the most deregulated genes between the 163 upper and lower respiratory tract tissues. Interestingly, many genes involved in the regulation 164 of the inflammatory response such as HOX1, IL1B, IL1A, IL17C are found amongst the most 165 upregulated genes in the nasal HAE model (Fig. 2A). These genes are also upregulated in the 166 bronchial HAE model (Extended data file 2). To provide further functional interpretation of the 167 superinfection signature, we performed a functional enrichment analysis, using the same 168 strategy previously described. We only observed a limited number of enriched clusters of 169 downregulated genes, mostly in bronchial HAE, all of them being related to epithelial 170 physiology and cell movement (e.g. cytoskeleton-dependent intracellular transport, protein 171 localization to cilium, cilium movement GO terms, Fig. 2C). In line with this observation, our 172 analysis highlighted several clusters of enriched upregulated genes related to epithelial 173 physiology (e.g. locomotion, movement of cell or subcellular component GO terms, Fig. 2C).

On the other hand, terms related to signaling, host response and immunity were markedly 175 more upregulated in the bronchial HAE model (Fig. 2C & Extended data Fig. 2 ). In addition 176 to the gene enrichment profile shared between the nasal and bronchial models, our study also 177 highlighted several overlapping biological processes such as the cytokine signaling and IL10 346 (https://www.uniprot.org/database/DB-0118) (Breuza et al., 2016; Maglott et al., 2005). First,

Uniprot entries associated to several gene IDs were removed. Indeed, we are not focused on 348 gene fusion products or read-through transcripts in this study. In case of a gene ID associated 349 to several Uniprot entries, only the best entry based on the reviewed status and the annotation 350 score was kept; if those values were not discriminant enough, only duplicated entries with a 351 reviewed status and an annotation score of 5 were kept. The protein-protein interaction (PPI) 352 network was analyzed with STRING 11.0 and visualized with Cytoscape 3.8.0. and Bacterial Interactions in the Upper Respiratory Tract. body_text.text: prevalence of superinfections associated with COVID-19, including invasive aspergillosis, but 23 the underlying mechanisms remain to be characterized. In the present study, to better 24 understand the biological impact of superinfection we sought to determine and compare the 25 host transcriptional response to SARS-CoV-2 versus Aspergillus superinfection, using a model 26 of reconstituted humain airway epithelium. Our analyses reveal that both simple infection and 27 superinfection induce a strong deregulation of core components of innate immune and 28 inflammatory responses, with a stronger response to superinfection in the bronchial epithelial 29 model compared to its nasal counterpart. Our results also highlight unique transcriptional 30 footprints of SARS-CoV-2 Aspergillus superinfection, such as an imbalanced type I/type III IFN, 31 and an induction of several monocyte-and neutrophil associated chemokines, that could be 32 useful for the understanding of Aspergillus-associated COVID-19 and but also management 33 of severe forms of aspergillosis in this specific context.

The current pandemic of novel coronavirus disease 2019 , caused by severe acute 37 respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) began in Wuhan, Hubei province, China, 38 in December 2019. As of May 18, 2020, there have been more than 4,628,903 confirmed 39 COVID-19 cases in the world as reported by the WHO, including 312,009 deaths (WHO). characterized and validated in terms of viral production, impact on trans-epithelial resistance hallmark of CoV+Asp superinfection, in contrast to CoV infection (Fig. 1D) . Similar observations were performed using different terms related to inflammation (Extended data Fig. 1 ), hence suggesting a very different inflammation signature resulting from superinfection.

Altogether, our results indicate that the CoV+Asp superinfection presents a transcriptomic 149 signature that recapitulates the overall signature of a simple CoV infection, but with both a 150 particularly distinct regulation of the inflammatory response and the additional regulation of 151 many biological processes related to the physiology of epithelia. Of note, we observed a 152 relatively similar global pattern of regulation between the nasal and bronchial HAE models, 153 differing primarily in the magnitude rather than the nature of the responses to CoV and 154 CoV+Asp superinfection.

In order to explore in more depth the transcriptomic signature of the superinfection, we then signaling pathways (Fig. 2C) , which is consistent with the most upregulated DEGs shown in 179 Fig. 2A and Extended data file 2. To better visualize these observations, we applied a protein-180 protein interactions analysis using STRING network to investigate the DEGs corresponding to 181 several Reactome and GO terms (immune system process, cytokine signaling in immune system, inflammatory response, interleukin-10 signaling) enriched in the bronchial and nasal superinfection signatures along with their functional interactions ( Fig. 3A and 3B Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA), which typically occurs in an immunocompromised host,

represents an important cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide (Clancy and Nguyen, 198 2020). Superinfections were extensively documented in the case of influenza infections, with 199 the latter being usually described to "pave the way" for bacterial superinfections, but several 200 severe influenza cases have also been reported to develop invasive pulmonary aspergillosis 201 5/19/2020 9:59:00 AM. An increasing amount of evidence points towards a relatively high 202 prevalence of superinfections, including invasive aspergillosis, to be associated with COVID-203 19 (Alanio et al., 2020; Lescure et al., 2020; Zhou et al., 2020) . However, the underlying 204 mechanisms remain to be characterized. In the present study, we sought to better understand (Pizzorno et al., 2020) . Whereas no major differences in terms of global superinfection signatures where observed between HAE models of nasal or bronchial origin, the second part of our study highlighted more subtle differences between the differences of infectivity and consecutive host responses between different cell subsets (type 225 II pneumocytes, nasal goblet secretory cells) are linked to varying ACE2/TMPRSS2 levels,

ACE2 expression being linked to the IFN response (Ziegler et al., 2020) . The discrepancies 227 we observed in the two HAE models could be explained by differences of cell type composition 228 that could be interesting to further explore using combinations of additional experimental 229 models, including ACE2/TMPRSS3 expression and single cell RNA-seq approaches.

FIGREF0.text: immune and inflammatory responses occurring in the context of a SARS-CoV-2 + Aspergillus superinfection. Interestingly, our analysis underlined the role of type III IFN (IFNL1, INFL2 and INFL3) and several cytokine-coding genes such as CXCL2/CXCL8 (Fig. 3A and 189 3B) that are upregulated following simple SARS-CoV-2 infection and even more upregulated 190 in the context of superinfection, arguably illustrating an enhanced specific response

FIGREF1.text: 205 the biological impact of superinfections by determining and comparing the host transcriptional 206 response to SARS-CoV-2 versus SARS-CoV-2 + Aspergillus superinfection. Collectively, our 207 results show a much stronger host response to superinfection in the bronchial epithelial model 208 compared to its nasal counterpart. In both models, functional analyses show that the SARS-209 CoV-2 + Aspergillus superinfection signature reflects important changes in the expression 210 regulation of genes involved not only in epithelium physiology but also in the regulation of host 211 immune and inflammatory responses compared to that of the simple SARS-CoV-2 infection. 212 213 The reconstituted HAE model of infection/superinfection appears as a valuable support for the 214 study of respiratory viral infections and virus-host interactions in highly biologically relevant 215 experimental conditions. Previous results by our group using this model, constituted of fully 216 differentiated and functional human primary cells, have provided meaningful contributions to 217 the characterization of the kinetics of viral infection as well as on the tissue-level remodeling line with our present observation

FIGREF2.text: of the superinfection signature revealed an important role of physiology and 232 cilium-related genes, which could reflect an additional negative impact of Aspergillus infection 233 on the epithelium integrity (trans-epithelial resistance, Fig. 1B) and mucociliary clearance, in 234 good agreement with previous observations by our group following different types of viral 235 infection in HAE (Nicolas de Lamballerie et al., 2019). In the specific context of SARS-CoV-2 236 infection, the additional deleterious effect on epithelium integrity induced by aspergillosis might 237 contribute to the enhanced disease severity reported in the clinic while arguably increasing the 238 risk of additional bacterial of fungal superinfections, similarly to what has been described in 239 the case of other respiratory viral infections (Smith et al., 2013; Wu et al., 2016).

FIGREF3.text: finding of our study relates to the impact of infection/superinfections on 242 interferon and inflammatory responses, notably when compared to the limited transcriptomic 243 data available in literature to date. Using primary cells, Blanco-Melo and colleagues recently 244 reported that SARS-CoV-2 induces limited IFN-I and III responses (Blanco-Melo et al., 2020).

FIGREF4.text: 246 limited involvement of the type I interferon response in the context of simple SARS-CoV-2 247 infection -in contrast with data previously obtained with other viruses (Nicolas de Lamballerie 248 et al., 2019), our analysis highlights an important upregulation of crucial genes involved in the 249 type IIII interferon response. This response is even more pronounced in the context of

FIGREF5.text: 250 superinfection (Fig. 3A and 3B). Type III interferon (IFN-λ) is known to play a key role in innate 251 and adaptive mucosal immune responses to infection(Ye et al., 2019). Interestingly, IFN-λ has 252 been identified as a critical regulator of neutrophil activation to prevent fungal infection such 253 as invasive pulmonary aspergillosis(Espinosa et al., 2017). Our data suggest a divergence 254 between type I and type III interferon responses, with enhanced activation of the latter in the 255 context of fungal superinfection. This characteristic response could be associated with increased neutrophil activation as an important first line of adaptive defense against these two the context of SARS-CoV-2 infection, in line with currently available clinical data from COVID-261 19 patients, which generally present high levels of circulating neutrophils(Chen et al., 2020;    262Qin et al., 2020). These observations support an important role of neutrophil recruitment in the 263 response to COVID-19, more particularly in the context of fungal superinfection with an 264 exacerbation of pro-inflammatory response. In that sense, the upregulation of key genes 265 belonging to the IL-10 pathway observed in our analysis(Fig. 2C), previously demonstrated to 266 play a deleterious role in innate resistance to systemic aspergillosis(Clemons et al., 2000),267constitutes an illustration of how such "enhanced" state of inflammation could contribute to 268 increase severity.269 270In conclusion, our transcriptional profiling approach revealed unique features of the SARS-271CoV-2 + Aspergillus superinfection signature, characterized on one side by an "enhanced"272 version of that induced by SARS-CoV infection, but also by specific changes on respiratory 273 tissue physiology, a distinct regulation of type I and type III interferons, and an over-induction 274 of inflammatory response. While we acknowledge that it would be rather bold to make a 275 statement on the possible severity associated with Aspergillus superinfection in a pre-existing 276 COVID-19 pathological context based solely on our results, our observations suggest that the 277 immunomodulation induced by SARS-CoV-2 infection could establish a favorable context for 278 the development of severe forms of aspergillosis .This could constitute an important aspect to 279 be considered for the immunological follow-up of COVID-19 patients with aspergillosis. On top 280 of that, the characteristic infection signatures described in this study provide valuable insight 281 in the perspective of possible future treatments targeting the COVID-19 inflammatory response, 282 which could result in counter-productive effects for the management of aspergillosis. the manufacturer's instructions. For infection experiments, apical poles were 290 gently washed twice with warm OptiMEM medium (Gibco, ThermoFisher Scientific) and then 291 infected directly with 150 l dilution of virus in OptiMEM medium, at a multiplicity of infection 292 (MOI) of 0.1 (Pizzorno et al., 2020). For mock infection, the same procedure was followed 293 using OptiMEM as inoculum. Superinfection was performed in SARS-CoV-2 infected cells at 294 48h post-infection, with apical inoculation of 10 l of Aspergillus in OptiMEM at a MOI of 1. 295 Samples were collected from apical washes or basolateral medium at 72h post infection. 296 Variations in transepithelial electrical resistance (TEER) were measured using a dedicated 297 volt-ohm meter (EVOM2, Epithelial Volt/Ohm Meter for TEER) and expressed as Ohm/cm2. involving clinical samples and the manipulation of infectious SARS-CoV-2 301 were performed in biosafety level 3 (BSL-3) facilities, using appropriate protocols. The 302 BetaCoV/France/IDF0571/2020 SARS-CoV-2 strain used in this study was isolated directly 303 from a patient sample as described elsewhere (Pizzorno et al., 2020). Viral stocks were 304 prepared and quantified in Vero E6 cells (TCID50/mL). Aspergillus niger (ATCC 16404) was 305 quantified on maltose extract agar plates (CFU/ml). was extracted using the RNeasy Mini Kit (QIAGEN, ref 74104) with DNase 309 treatment, following the manufacturer's instruction. 500 μg total RNA was used to prepare 310 polyA-enriched RNA-seq libraries using the KAPA mRNA Hyper Prep Kit (Roche, ref. 311 KK8581/KK8581). Those libraries were prepared separately for each sample with 11 312 amplification cycles, then all libraries were equimolar-pooled before sequencing. Paired-end 313 sequencing (2×100bp) was performed with Illumina NovaSeq 6000 sequencing platform on a 314 SP flowcell (Illumina, ref: 20040326).
